source: # Guidelines for authors

The journal makes use of **ipynb notebooks** to publish the articles. In addition to that, there is a couple of rules to *format content* and *visualize datasets*. The article shall be written in English (and thus use English style typography).
# QuickGuide

1. Get [Jupyter Notebook](https://jupyter.org/index.html).
2. Activate [nbextensions](https://jupyter-contrib-nbextensions.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install.html) “collapsible headings” and “table of contents”.
3. Connect [cite2c](https://github.com/takluyver/cite2c) of nbextension with your Zotero account (and in there join the [JDH group](https://www.zotero.org/groups/2784584/jdh)).
4. Create a [Github](https://github.com/) repository.
5. Download the [Jupyter Notebook Template](https://github.com/C2DH/jdh-notebook/blob/master/author_guideline_template.ipynb).
6. Start writing your article, tag the beginning cells according to this guide and tag all hermeneutic cells.
7. Commit your notebook to Github and view the rendered article.
8. Submit your notebook for peer review.
9. View your published article.
# Setting up your writing environment
## Jupyter installation
### Install jupyter

- Refer to [this](https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/tutorial-jupyter-notebook) or [this tutorial](https://jupyter-notebook-beginner-guide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for a quick guide in jupyter notebook.
- [Here](https://medium.com/game-of-data/12-things-to-know-about-jupyter-notebook-markdown-3f6cef811707) is a refresher on markdown 
- and [here](https://towardsdatascience.com/jypyter-notebook-shortcuts-bf0101a98330) you’ll find some useful keyboard hotkeys.
### Activate the nbextension

1. Run the requirements.txt of this GitHub project with the following command in the console:

`pip install -r requirements.txt`

Or run the following command in the console:

`pip install jupyter_contrib_nbextensions`

2. Activate the library by clicking the jupyter logo and go to the tab "Nbextension"
figure 1: nbextension
### Activate the necessary plugin (cite2c)

For citation management, we use the cite2c plugin. It connects your Zotero library to the notebook and inserts the citations into the markdown cells. The citations are stored in the notebook metadata and references by an ID. It also renders a bibliography and inline citations.
Zotero is an open-source reference management software to manage bibliographic data and related research material.

1. Install it with the following command:

`python -m pip install cite2c`

2. Check if cite2c is activated in the Nbextension tab in jupyter.
figure 2: cite2c in nbextensions

3. Open a notebook and select the button “Cite” in the toolbar. You will be asked to sign into your [Zotero](https://www.zotero.org/) account if you already are a user or you create a new account first.
figure 3: cite button
4. Make sure you are part of the [JournalofDigitalHistory](https://www.zotero.org/journalofdigitalhistory) group in Zotero (if not request to join).

5. If you want to add a citation to your article, simply select the “Cite” button. Type the keywords of the citation you are looking for in the search bar. Press the “Insert” button to add the citation to your notebook cell. Execute the cell.
figure 4: search for citation in cite2c from your Zotero library
figure 5: inline citation in markdown
figure 6: inline citation in executed cell
6. If you want to show your entire biography in the last cell of your notebook, click the “Insert bibliography” button in the toolbar.
figure 7: insert bibliography
7. Execute the cell to see the result.
figure 8: view rendered bibliography
### Added features: table of contents, collapsible headings
To keep a better overview of your notebook, we suggest you use these three additional features.
1. In nbextension, select the **table of contents** feature to activate it. Open a notebook. In the toolbar select the table of contents button to show it as a sidebar next to the notebook.
figure 9: table of contents

2. In nbextension, select the **collapsible headings** feature to activate it. Open a notebook. You will see the triangle next to each cell. You can easily expand or contract it. This way you can hide certain section to keep a better overview of your progress.
figure 10: collapsible headings
## Github account

While working in the notebooks, every author needs to create a Github repository (per article). You can create your own repository [here](https://github.com/).

In order to review the author’s notebooks, the authors need to provide access rights in Github to the user [jdh-observer](https://github.com/jdh-observer).
### Folder structure
When delivering the notebook, we require the following files in this precise folder structure:
table 1: folder structure & required files in Github

File |Type | Explanation
--- | --- | ---
readme | .md file | This file contains the abstract of the article and the keywords.
requirements | .txt file | This file contains all the versions of the required libraries to function properly.
notebook | .ipynb file | This file is placed in the root folder and contains the full title of the article, separating the words with "-" inbetween
media | folder | This folder contains all media like images, videos, etc.
script | folder | This folder contains all the code and data needed for the notebook like the CSV-files.
[Here](https://github.com/biumiamy/Example_Notebook) is an example for the folder structure in a repository:
figure 11: repository folder structure
Every article will have a **launch binder** button implemented for a quick (read-only) view of the notebook.

For the filename naming, please adhere to the following guidelines:
- no space in the name
- no point but for the extension
- no upper case (only lower case)
- if a date is at the beginning of the name: YYYYMMDD
- english quotemarks
# Writing: structuring the notebook
## Tagging

In order to render the notebook on the frontend, we are working with tags to mark special content like figures, tables or the narrative and hermeneutics layer. 

Here's an overview of the most important tags:
table 2: tagging for all content types

Function | Tag | Markdown | Explanation
--- | --- | --- | ---
Title | `title` | h1 (#) | This tag is used for the title of the article. 
Contributors | `contributors` | h3 (###) | List the contributors. Below the name, indicate the role and the affiliation.
Cover Image | `cover` | | Figures are counted automatically and will appear in the table of figures. (Captions will be added via a button?)
Disclaimer | `disclaimer` | | This disclaimer can be used for certain announcements. It will be color-coded in orange.
Keywords | `keywords` | | Keywords are to be separated by comma (“,”)
Abstract | `abstract` | | This cell features the abstract of an article with a max./min length of x characters.
Chapter Title | | h2 (##) | Chapter titles are always written in h2. 
Table | `table-1` | | For tables, **individually** tag each table in the order like this: table-1, table-2, table-3.
Figure | `figure-1` | figure 1a, figure 1b | Figures need to be tagged with "figure-(number)". Captions are added manually.
Hermeneutics | `hermeneutics` |  | Methodology is always placed on the hermeneutics layer.
For the header section we us the tags `title`, `contributors`, `cover`, `disclaimer` (if needed), `keywords` and `abstract` to show the article in a certain structure.
## Hermeneutics
The articles in our journal have a unique layer approach which is also reflected in the way the notebooks are written.
table 3: hermeneutics use cases

Use Case | Function | Tag | Markdown | Explanation
--- | --- | --- | --- | ---
1 | Hermeneutics | `hermeneutics` | | Everything related to hermeneutics should be tagged accordingly.
2 | Input on the hermeneutics layer, output on the narrative layer | `hermeneutics` `narrative` | | Sometimes it makes sense to have code input on the hermeneutics layer, but the output should be visible on the narrative layer as part of the story the author wants to tell. Tag both for these cases.
3 | Hermeneutics Step | `hermeneutics-step` | | Break long passages into a step by step manner to facilitate understanding while showing something visual.
### Use cases
#### Use Case 1: Hermeneutics
Everything that refers to the methodology will be placed on the hermeneutics layer. The cells should be tagged with `hermeneutics`.
On the frontend, these cells will appear in a collapsed accordion that can be expanded when needed.
#### Use Case 2: Input H-layer, output N-layer

Sometimes it makes sense to have code input on the hermeneutics layer, but the output should be visible on the narrative layer as part of the story the author wants to tell. For this special case, we recommend tagging `hermeneutics` and `narrative`.
## Narrative and hermeneutics steps (TBD - Issue #2)

Using visuals can often support how a certain methodology is setup. For this purpose, there's a special method we can use by tagging `hermeneutics-step` for the hermeneutics layer or `narrative-step` when on the narrative layer.
Here's an example of how this could look like:

text/html: Scrollytelling

source:
HTML('

Scrollytelling

')
## Captions for figures & tables
Figures and tables are a bit special. Depending on the type of cell there are the following use cases and guides on writing a caption:
table 4: captions for figure & table

Use Case | Cell Type | Content Type | Tag | Caption 
--- | --- | --- | --- | ----
1 | Code | figure | `figure-1` | The caption is directly added in the metadata of the code cell.
2 | Code | figure-1, figure-2 | `figure-1` | The caption is directly added in the metadata of the code cell for each figure. The cell caption is written via the cell metadata.
3 | Code | Table | `table-1` | The caption is directly added in the metadata of the code cell.
4 | Markdown | Table | `table-1` | The caption is written via the cell metadata.
### Use Cases
#### Use case 1: figure in code cell
#### Use case 2: two figures in one code cell

If a cell is supposed to contain two figures in one cell, we propose the following cell-centric approach:
* write the caption for `figure 1a` and `figure 1b` separately directly in the code cell

`'figure 1a: First Caption'
'figure 1b: Second Caption'`
* tag the cell with `figure-1`
* modify the cell metadata to add the caption for the whole cell
figure 12: activate *view metadata* in cell toolbar
figure 12: write one cell caption for the figure(s)
#### Use case 3: table in code cell
Use case 3 uses the same principles as use case 1 and 2. Just replace `figure` with `table`.
#### Use case 4: table in markdown cell
For writing a caption for a table in a markdown cell, add the caption via the cell metadata.
figure 13: write one cell caption for the table(s)
## Tagging with color-coded cells (TBD)

In order to see what content has what cell in one glance, we recommend using the **color-coded cell** feature. 

To install it, simply enter the following command:

`pip install nb_extension_tagstyler`

Here's an overview of which cell tag was paired with which color:
- figure: yellow
- table: green
- hermeneutics: blue
figure 14: color-coded cells assigned to specific tags
After you added a tag to a cell, in order to view the assigned cell color, you need to reload the notebook in your browser.
## Submitting

- For the peer review, we need two versions of the notebook, anonymized and a non anonymized version. 
- Submit **both version** via a private or public repo on Github 
- Send an email to mailto:jdh.admin@uni.lu when done.
